Comments_List: I learned a lot about representation theory of finite groups and Lie groups.

The first half of the course covers the representation theory of finite groups. The second half switches to continuous groups and therefore it is useful to have some knowledge of Lie theory although the basics are taught in this course.
Phil gave a good comprehensive coverage of the topic. The pace was good.
This course's greatest strength is that it is taught in a modern setting using the language of category theory.

This is a good class and Phil is a good teacher. Although there are few formal prerequisites, it's really best that you've already taken 350. You'll also benefit from having done some category theory, but this is not necessary. There is a very well developed theory of representations of finite groups over C, and there's so much structure so it's pretty nice to learn about. Much of the Lie group unit focussed on Lie groups and algebras as opposed to their representations, but that's also good to know. The courseload is reasonable - will take some time, but nothing crazy.

Yes, however be prepared to work extremely hard. Take modern algebra first. Only then is this course valuable for any math major who is interested in understanding the Langlands Program. A physics major can learn the material she/he needs in an easier and perhaps more useful setting than this. This is not the kind of course you can credit/D.
